section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This hands-on programming section introduces fundamental concepts of variables and data types in Python. Students will learn to create, assign, and manipulate variables while exploring numeric types (integers, floats, complex), text strings, boolean values, and None. Through practical exercises and coding challenges, students will develop proficiency in Python's dynamic typing system and understand type conversion methods essential for robust programming.
learning_objectives: Create and assign variables using valid Python naming conventions
Distinguish and use different numeric data types (int, float, complex)
Perform string operations including concatenation, indexing, and formatting
Apply boolean logic and understand truthy/falsy values
Implement type conversion functions and identify common type errors
Debug variable-related issues using print statements and type checking

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to declare variables with appropriate naming conventions and understand Python's dynamic typing system through hands-on practice.
key_topics: Identifier naming rules and best practices (PEP 8)
Dynamic typing vs static typing concepts

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for storing personal information: name, age, height, and is_student. Assign appropriate values and verify the data types using the type() function. Print each variable and its type.
Fix the invalid variable names in this code: 1name = 'John', age-limit = 25, class = 'Python'. Explain why each original name is invalid and provide corrected versions that follow Python conventions.
Use multiple assignment to swap the values of two variables x = 10 and y = 20 without using a temporary variable. Demonstrate the swap and print the before/after values.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform arithmetic operations and understand the differences between integer, float, and complex number types in Python.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a program that performs basic arithmetic operations between two user-provided numbers. Include addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, integer division, and modulo. Handle division by zero gracefully.

Investigate floating-point precision by creating two variables: a = 0.1 and b = 0.2. Calculate a + b and compare the result to 0.3. Use the decimal module to show the difference and explain the concept of floating-point representation errors.
Create two complex numbers (e.g., 3+4j and 1-2j) and perform addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Calculate the magnitude of each complex number using abs() and verify the results.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create, format, and manipulate strings using various string methods and interpolation techniques.
key_topics: String creation and quoting styles (single, double, triple quotes)
Common string methods (upper(), lower(), split(), join())

exercises.exercise_instructions: Given the string 'Python Programming', extract and print: the first 6 characters, the last 11 characters, every second character, and the string in reverse order. Demonstrate all slicing techniques.

Create a program that takes user input for name, age, and city. Format the information using f-strings to create a formatted presentation: 'Hello, my name is [name]. I am [age] years old and I live in [city].'

Take a sentence input from the user and perform the following operations: count total characters, count words, convert to uppercase, replace all 'a' with '@', and display the first and last characters. Handle edge cases like empty input.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to work with boolean values, understand truthy/falsy concepts, and use None for representing absence of value.
key_topics: Comparison operators and their boolean results
Truthy and falsy values in Python

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a list of different values: [0, 1, -1, '', 'hello', [], [1], None, False, True]. Use a loop to test each value in a boolean context and print whether each is truthy or falsy. Explain the results.

Create a program that takes two numbers as input and compares them using all comparison operators (<, <=, ==, !=, >, >=). Print the results of each comparison and explain the difference between = and ==.

Create variables with None values and demonstrate how to check for None using 'is' comparison. Create a function that returns None and show how to handle this return value in different scenarios. Include an example of optional parameters with None defaults.
